(2) I am advised that the Department was told on that day that the briefing was cancelled. The reason for the cancellation would have to be sought from the Committee.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) In response to my question without notice (Hansard, 12 April 2000, page 15119) regarding transparency in wholesale petrol pricing, did he say that when the recommendation of the ACCC was put to the Australian Senate to deregulate the petroleum industry at the retail level, it was opposed by a political party which was more interested in keeping up differential rates for rural and regional people than in acting on that recommendation and bringing the differential down; if so, was the legislation to which he referred the Petroleum Retail Legislation Repeal Bill 1998.

(2) If so, (a) did that legislation pass the House of Representatives on 11 March 1999, (b) was it introduced to the Senate on 22 March 1999 and (c) does it remain on the Senate Notice Paper under Government Business, undebated and not voted on; if so, does he stand by his statement in response to my question; if not, (d) to which legislation was he referring and (e) how was it opposed by the Senate.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Hansard (12 April 2000, page 15119) contains an accurate record of my response to your question without notice. The legislation to which I was referring was the Petroleum Retail Legislation Repeal Bill 1998.

(2) (a) Yes. (b) Yes. (c) Yes: Following the return from the 1999 winter recess, the Government held extensive negotiations with the non-Government parties in the Senate on its reform package and associated Repeal Bill. The non-Government parties would not agree to the passage of the Repeal Bill at that time.

At the same time the Government sought to implement part of the reform package through a temporary increase in BP's quota under the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act — by way of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.2). In September 1999 Labor and the Democrats combined to disallow these Regulations, making reference to their desire to retain the Sites Act for at least another two years.

As a result of the non-Government parties' decision to oppose the reform package and associated Repeal Bill and their vote to disallow regulations associated with the deregulation of the petroleum industry at the retail level, the Government has decided not to proceed with the Repeal Bill until the major participants in the industry agree on the petroleum reform package.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Mobile and Manufactured Home Sales
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1488)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 May 2000:

quote.para: On selling their homes, will the owners of mobile homes or manufactured homes be treated in the same way as other home owners in that the price of their home will be GST free.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The sale of a mobile home or a manufactured home used for residential accommodation will not be subject to GST if it is sold by an individual who is not engaged in the enterprise of selling mobile homes or manufactured homes. This is how the majority of used mobile homes and established manufactured homes are expected to be sold.

Established manufactured or demountable housing comes within the definition of residential premises and will be input taxed on sale if it is affixed to land. Supplies of demountable buildings that are not residential premises will not be subject to GST unless sold in the course of an enterprise that is carried on.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 9 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the Australian Conservation Foundation Report in Habitat Australia 2000 concerning the Snowy River.

(2) Have water savings in the Murray-Darling generated by the expenditure of tens of millions of Natural Heritage Trust dollars been used to increase the flow of the Murray-Darling, or have they been used to allow expansion in irrigated agriculture.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Natural Heritage Trust projects with the potential to generate water savings are those funded through the Murray-Darling 2001 Program and the National Landcare Program. These projects aim at improving water use efficiency either on or off-farm. Eligible activities for Trust funding include:
. improved on-farm irrigation management practices
. installation of more efficient on-farm irrigation systems
. refurbishment or upgrading of off-farm water delivery systems
. recycling of drainage water
. demonstration activities on farms and training and education courses.
It is also relevant that any expansion of irrigated agriculture can only take place within the water allocations available under the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council `Cap' on diversions.

Most Natural Heritage Trust projects submitted for funding by the Basin community have been dominated by issues of water quality; control of water-tables to manage salinity and associated downstream impacts; riverine corridor restoration and protection; and improved aquatic habitat.

The Murray-Darling 2001 Program has recently developed a new Irrigation and Water Use Efficiency component, which has as objectives: encouraging adoption of improved irrigation management practices; improving distribution system efficiency and security of water supply to irrigators; improving the management of water reuse systems; and providing additional water for environmental flows.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 10 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to part (2) of question No 1212 (Hansard, 9 May 2000, page 16103), why was a detailed assessment of the financial impact of handing back Employment National's (EN) Job Network 1 contracts not undertaken before the contracts were handed back.

(5) Did the Minister for Employment Services, the Minister's advisers or the Minister's Department, discuss his direction to EN to hand back the contracts with him, his advisers or his Department before that decision was made; if so, did he, his advisers or his Department express a view as to whether the contracts should be handed back; if so, what was that view.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) An assessment of the financial impact of handing back EN's Intensive Assistance (Flex 3) Job Network 1 contracts was undertaken for EN by its accounting advisers. Based on advice from EN management, that assessment assumed that EN would cease servicing Intensive Assistance clients under Job Network 1, apart from those placed in sustainable employment prior to the commencement of W2, given the large losses associated with the business.

(2) EN advises that the costings are based on projections of minimum costs required to continue to service Intensive Assistance clients. The costs included a reducing profile of staff required to service ongoing Intensive Assistance clients, property, IT and telephony costs for those staff, (including appropriate adjustments to systems, and maintaining sites that would otherwise have closed) and candidate 1 extra' expenditure. The costing assumptions did not include consideration of staff retention payments for staff with short term futures in the company.

(b) This advertising was paid.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 11 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many of the intensive assistance initial outcomes for which a provider has received a payment under the Job Network to date are (a) training outcomes and (b) paid work.
(2) How many of the intensive assistance 13 week outcomes for which a provider h received a payment under the Job Network to date are (a) training outcomes and (b) paid work.
(3) What portion of the total does the training outcome represent.
(4) What percentage of sum spent under the Job Network is on accredited training.
(5) What was the total sum spent on accredited training in the last 12 months.
(6) How many long term unemployed were placed into employment in the first 19 months of the Job Network.
(7) How many long term unemployed were scheduled to be placed into employment in the first 19 months of the Job Network.
(8) How many job seekers were placed into employment in the first 19 months of the Job Network.
(9) How many job seekers were scheduled to be placed into employment in the first 19 months of the Job Network.
(10) How many job seekers in total have been placed in work in the last 12 months.
(11) How many intensive assistance clients have been placed in work in the last 12 months.
(12) How many non intensive assistance job seekers have been placed in work in the last 12 months.
(13) How many providers missed out on contracts under Job Network 2 because their bids faded to comply with the revised GST guidelines.
(14) How many Job Network sites are located within 50 metres of each other.
(15) What are the-locations of these Job Network sites.
(16) Counting, Job Network sites located within 50 metres of each other as one site, what is the number of sites under Job Network 2.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) (a) nil - see (2) (b) nil - see (2)

(2) (a) An Intensive Assistance outcomes payment is made when a job seeker who has been placed in a job or an education/training course remains in the course for a semester or continues to receive income sufficient to result in a M or partial reduction in income support payments over a period of 13 consecutive weeks. These 13 week outcomes are referred to as interim outcomes. From 1 May 1998 to 19 May 2000, a total of 4648 interim outcomes payments were made for the placement of job seekers into education or training.

(b) From 1 May 1998 to 19 May 2000, a total of 68 287 interim outcomes payments were made for the placement of job seekers into employment. The placement into a job which '4anchors' such a 13 week outcome may be eligible for a payment under Job Matching arrangements.
(3) Education and training placements are 6.4 percent of interim outcomes.

(4) and (5) Accredited training is not a separate service within Job Network. Job Network members are not required to account for expenditure on various forms of assistance to clients. The department cannot, therefore, report on expenditure on accredited training within Job Network.
(6) In the first 19 months of Job Network operation around 165 000 Job Matching placements were for long term unemployed job seekers.
(7) There was no target for the placement of long term unemployed job seekers in the first 19 months of Job Network.
(8) Around 440 000 eligible Job Matching placements (potentially attracting, a Job Matching fee) were achieved in the first 19 months of Job Network operation.
(9) There was no target for the placement of job seekers in the first 19 months of Job Network.
(10) Approximately 293 000 eligible Job Matching placements were achieved in the 12 months to end April 2000.
(11) Around 90 000 eligible Job Matching placements were made for Intensive Assistance participants in the 12 months to end April. 2000.
(12) In the 12 months to end April 2000 around 203 000 eligible Job Matching placements were for job seekers who were not participating in Intensive Assistance.
(13) Twenty-nine organisations were not considered for contracts to deliver Intensive Assistance
services for the sole reason that they submitted prices all of which were below the
minimum price specified in the GST related addendum to the Request for Tender.
(14), (15) and (16) As at 23 May 2000, there were 2054 Job Network sites. The department records the addresses of sites; it does not measure the distance between sites.

subdebateinfo.title: Dairy Industry Deregulation Community Assistance Package: Tasmanian Allocation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1557)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 29 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) What proportion of the Dairy Industry Deregulation Community Assistance Package will be allocated to Tasmania.
(2) What process is in place for the application for funding under this program.
(3) What process is in place for the assessment of applications.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Dairy Regional Assistance Program (Dairy RAP) is but one component of the Dairy Structural Adjustment Package. Under Dairy RAP, there is no specific allocation on a state by state basis. Funding allocations will therefore be assessed nationally in the light of the numbers and types of funding requests received, the information provided by the proponents in their applications and the advice from their respective Area Consultative Committee(s).

(2) Procedures for application and funding for the program are currently being developed between my department and the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. (3) The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business is developing, in consultation with my department, a process for consideration of applications. Initial applications will need to be lodged through Area Consultative Committees.

Area Consultative Committees, which work in partnership with government, business and the community will put forward for consideration applications which demonstrate the capacity to create sustainable regional employment opportunities and/or services that lead to ongoing regional benefits.

subdebateinfo.title: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: Research Facilities Closure
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1570)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 29 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) Does the Minister support the closure of the CSIRO research facility at Prospect.
(2) When did the Minister first become aware of a report into the CSIRO's Livestock Research Infrastructure.
(3) When did the Minister first become aware of proposals to close the CSIRO research facility at Prospect.
(4) Have there been discussions between the Minister's Department and Boral Quarries at Prospect; if so, what was the (a) date and (h) nature of the discussions.
(5) Have arrangements been made in regard to the future use of the site by Boral Quarries or any other company.
(6) What plans have been made for the future usage of the site.
(7) Was there a $12 million upgrade of the CSIRO Prospect facility in 1995; if so, what specific areas of the site were upgraded and what was the individual cost of each area upgraded.

(8) What sum of Commonwealth funding was allocated to the CSIRO research facility at Prospect in (a) 1990-91, (b) 1991-92, (c) 1992-93, (d) 1993-94, (e) 1994-95, (f) 1995-96, (g) 1996-97, (h) 1997-98, (i) 1998-99 and (j) 1999-2000.

(9) Did the Minister receive advice detailing the closure of the CSIRO's research facility at Prospect; if so, (a) on what date was the advice received and (b) did the advice state that the closure of the facility would (i) involve the loss of highly skilled research staff currently stationed at Prospect and result in the closure of the several research programs owing to the loss of key scientific expertise, (ii) at the least, incur months of disruption to research programs of national importance to the $7 billion Livestock Industry that would affect producers across Australia and (iii) cut established links between the CSIRO's Prospect facility and the animal nutrition, pig and dairy industries in the Greater Sydney region.
(10) What sum of Commonwealth money has been appropriated to allow for relocation for staff and equipment, recruitment of new staff and redundancy packages for staff from the Prospect site.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's questions:

quote.para: (1) CSIRO's decision to close the Prospect facility flows from recommendations by a committee of senior industry representatives in a Review of Livestock Research Infrastructure commissioned in December 1999 by the Organisation's Chief Executive. CSIRO's response to this report is a matter for CSIRO.
(2) CSIRO advised the Minister about the deliberations of the Review of Livestock Research Infrastructure on 14 April 2000.

(3) On 14 April 2000, CSIRO advised the Minister that the Review Team was considering recommending that CSIRO's research facility at Prospect be closed. CSIRO's decision to accept the Review recommendation that the Prospect research facility be closed was communicated to the Minister on 15 May 2000.
(4)(a)(b) In 1998/99 Boral initiated a State Environment Planning Policy 59 proposal for redevelopment of its site for employment and residential uses.

In 1998 CSIRO lodged a proposal with Holroyd Council for the rezoning of 18 hectares of the Prospect site which was surplus to requirements. This area, about one third of the total site area, has been designated for disposal once rezoning is approved.

The Boral site is adjacent to CSIRO's Prospect site and, as two adjoining owners with concurrent planning proposals, CSIRO and Boral were required to reach agreement on joint access and services to the development areas.
CSIRO had a number of discussions with Boral in late 1999 and early 2000 on a possible Boral lease of a building in CSIRO's Prospect site (Building 35). This lease did not proceed.
(5) No. CSIRO does not have any arrangements or agreements with Boral or any other company about the future use of CSIRO's Prospect site.

(6) Other than the disposal of the 18 hectares of land surplus to requirements (see response to Q 4) CSIRO has not made any plans for the future use of the balance of the Prospect site. A property strategy is being developed by CSIRO and its equity partner, the Woolmark Company, on the future use of the balance of the site.
(7) A total of $9.2 million was expended in 1994/95 on facilities at Prospect comprising:
- a new facility for the McMaster Laboratory at a cost of $4.5 million
- refurbishment of certain existing facilities including the library, theatrette, climate control building, post mortem facility and animal house at a total cost of $4.7 million.

(8) Funding has not been specifically allocated to the Prospect site. In CSIRO funds are allocated to programs and not sites. CSIRO Animal Production has had staff located at up to nine different sites over the last decade and some programs are carried out on several of these sites.
Commonwealth funding allocated to CSIRO's Division of Animal Production as a whole, is:
(9) (a) CSIRO advised the Minister in writing on 15 May 2000 of its decision to accept the Review Committee's recommendation that the Prospect site be closed.

(b) (i) CSIRO advised the Minister that all staff at Prospect would be offered relocation with their jobs to other CSIRO sites and that it aims to maximise the number of staff that transfer to other locations by taking all practical measures to provide attractive relocation packages and minimise the stress of relocation. CSIRO also advised that, despite this, some staff might be unable to relocate and will instead opt for redundancy.
(ii) Advice from CSIRO noted the possibility of short to medium term disruption to some research groups, possibly including the loss of work areas to CSIRO.

(iii) An Implementation Team has been commissioned by CSIRO to ensure the orderly withdrawal from the Prospect site and to ensure the most appropriate relocation destinations for research groups into order to maintain and extend their industry links.
(10) No additional Commonwealth money has been appropriated for this purpose.

subdebateinfo.title: South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Cooperation Agreement: Garments from Fiji
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1574)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 29 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) Will proposed changes to the South Pacific regional trade and economic cooperation agreement allow garments made in Fiji from non-Australian woven fabric to be provided duty free into Australia.
(2) Does this have the potential to adversely affect Australian manufacturers in the wool weaving and conversion industries.
(3) What action will the Minister take to ensure manufacturers like ADA in Bendigo are not disadvantaged by the changes.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The proposed new arrangements provide for preferential access for TCF goods produced in Forum Island Countries (including Fiji), and incorporates a change in the method for utilising local area content for TCF goods. The local area content of a product is the input from Australia, New Zealand or Forum Island Countries. This new approach broadens the range of products able to be produced economically in a Forum Island Country.

(2) The Minister's intention is that the proposed new scheme will not disadvantage Australian textile producers and he has instructed his Department accordingly. The Department of Industry, Science and Resources has had extensive and ongoing consultation with industry to discuss the nature of the scheme.
(3) Representatives of ADA in Bendigo have been involved in the consultation process and their concerns will be taken into account in the finalisation of the new scheme.

(4) For each post referred to in part (3), how many visa applications were (a) received and (b) rejected from applicants aged (i) between 20 and 30 years of age, (ii) between 30 and 40 years of age, (iii) between 40 and 50 years of age, (iv) between 50 and 60 years of age and (v) 60 years of age and over.

(5) For each post referred to in parts (1) and (3), how many applications for visitor visas in each age group were refused on the grounds that the applicant fitted into one of the categories on the High Risk Factor List.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The honourable member will know that the Australian Government does not have posts in all of the countries listed in his question. However, all the data available at this time is included in Table A below. Until November 1998 the Department could only report on refusals by Post, and this was not always indicative of citizenship. From that time the Department has been able to report on refusals by citizenship and accordingly I have also included data, at Table B below, on applications and refusals by citizenship for calendar years 1999 and 2000 (to 31 May).

(2) Data on the age and sex of visitor visa applicants is not readily available for reporting purposes at present however systems development work is currently underway to enable data to be easily extracted and reported upon. I have asked officers of my Department to continue to advance this work and provide these statistics to the honourable member when they become available. Given the current position of the systems development, it is not possible to estimate when this information might be available.

(3) The honourable member will be aware of the difficulty in making comparisons between the countries discussed in question 1 and the USA and UK. US and UK citizens are eligible, along with the nationals of 31 low risk countries worldwide, to be granted an Electronic Travel Authority (ETA) if they are not listed on the Movement Alert List. Visitor visas, including ETAs, granted to UK and USA nationals during the period requested are included in Tables A and B.
(4) See (2) above.

(5) Public Interest Criterion 4011 (the “risk factor”) requires any visitor visa applicant who falls within certain age and sex cohorts to demonstrate to the decision-maker that “there is very little likelihood that the applicant will remain after the expiry of any period during which the applicant might be authorised to remain after entry.”
While I can state the number of visa applications rejected, the department does not record the reasons for those rejections in a way that can be accessed by the Department's reporting systems.

I can, however, state that the risk factor list is not used to automatically exclude applicants. It operates simply as an “alert” to decision-makers of the potential for continued stay in Australia and requires the applicant to provide a higher level of evidence to support their claim that they are only intending to visit Australia. An applicant will be rejected where they fail to satisfy a decision-maker that a genuine visit is intended.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Informal advice has been provided to my Department by ATO that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs staff will need to vacate the premises on the expiry of the sublease in May 2002.
(2) Relocation would be organised to minimise disruption to clients.
(3) 185 staff.

(4) The Perth Office's functions include the full range of services provided by a State/Regional office. This includes client services, citizenship processing, visa processing, compliance activities, settlement activities and a range of corporate functions to support office activities.
(5) My Department is not currently moving staff from its premises, but it would need to do so prior to lease expiry in May 2002.
(6) No premises have been selected at this point in time.
(7) Removal costs are estimated to be $60,000.
(8) The costs of furnishings and ancillaries in new premises are estimated to be around $2m.
